Michies Jurisprudence. For related discussion, see 4B M.J. Corporations, §§ 264, 266, 268; 15 M.J. Receiv ers, § 12. CASE NOTES Editors note. Some of the cases below were decided under prior law. This statute is remedial in nature and should be liberally construed. Baylor v. Beverly B ook Co., 216 Va. 22, 216 S.E.2d 18, 1975 Va. LEXIS 243 (1975). This section provides an additional remedy for protection of rights of stockholders, par ticularly minority stockholders. This remedy is in addition to the rights theretofore afforded stockholders under both the state law and the corporations charter and bylaws. Baylor v. Beverly Book Co., 216 Va. 22, 216 S.E.2d 18, 1975 Va. LEXIS 243 (1 975). This section supersedes a stockholders common-law right of action against directors for oppression, and limits a plaintiffs remedies to those available under the statute, namely dissolution or the appointment of a custodian. Jordon v. Bowman Apple Prods. Co., 728 F. Supp. 409, 1990 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 213 (W.D. Va. 1990). The word oppressive does not necessarily savor of fraud, and the absence of  mismanagement, or misapplication of assets, does not prevent a finding that the conduct of the dominant directors or officers has been oppressive. White v. Perkins, 213 Va. 129, 189 S.E.2d 315, 1972 Va. LEXIS 318 (1972). Oppressive is not synonymous with illegal and fraudulent. White v. Perkins, 213 Va. 129, 189 S.E.2d 315, 1972 Va. LEXIS 318 (1972). The word oppressive, as used in this section does not carry an essential inference of imminent disaster; it can contemplate a continuing course of conduct . White v. Perkins, 213 Va. 129, 189 S.E.2d 315, 1972 Va. LEXIS 318 (1972). As used in this section, oppressive means conduct by corporate managers toward stockholders which departs from the standards of fair dealing and violates the principles of fair play on which persons who entrust their funds to a corporation are entitled to rely. The term does not mean that a corporate disaster may be imminent and does not necessarily mean fraudulent conduct. Indeed, oppressive is not synonymous with the statutory terms illegal or fraudulent. The term can contemplate a continuous course of conduct and includes a lack of probity in corporate affairs to the prejudice of some of its shareholders. Giannotti v. Hamway , 239 Va. 14, 387 S.E.2d 725, 6 Va. Law Rep. 942, 1990 Va. LEXIS 3 (1990) (decided under former § 13.1-94). Weight of chancellors finding of oppressive conduct.  A finding of fact by the chancellor, hearing evidence ore tenus that conduct was oppressive under this section carries the weight of a jury verdict, and cannot be disturbed on appeal unless plainly wrong or without evidence to support it. White v. Perkins, 213 Va. 129, 189 S.E.2d 315, 1972 Va. LEXIS 318 (1972). Procedure upon finding oppression.  It is clear from this section that the court, upon finding oppression, could have decreed dissolution. It is also clear that it could have appointed a custodian w ith power to continue the business, including the payment of dividends, if the chancellor was convinced from the evidence that this action was in the best interest of the stockholders. White v. Perkins, 213 Va. 129, 189 S.E.2d 315, 1972 Va. LEXIS 318 (19 72). Upon a finding of oppression under this section, it was error for the trial court to decree: that the corporation should declare a dividend; that the majority sto ckholders claims against the company should be disallowed; that the amount owing to the company by a business controlled by the majority stockholder should be kept reasonably current in the future; and that the minority stockholder, whose employment with the company had been terminated, should be paid severance pay. White v. Perkins, 213 Va. 129, 189 S.E.2d 315, 1972 Va. LEXIS 318 (1972). Power of courts of equity.  The General Assembly has cloaked courts of equity with, in the words of the statute, full power to liquidate in a proper case where oppressive conduct has been established. The remedy specified by the legislature, while discretionary, is exclusive, and does not permit the trial court to fashion other, apparently equitable remedies. Giannotti v. Hamway, 239 Va. 14, 387 S.E.2d 725, 6 Va. Law Rep. 942, 1990 Va. LEXIS 3 (1990) (decided under former § 13.1-94). Intervention of court not justified.  In action by majority stockholder to dissolve corporation because the principal purpose for which corporation was formed was alleged to have failed, it was held t hat the circumstances revealed by the evidence did not justify the intervention of a court of equity in the internal affairs of the corporation and a substitution of its judgment for the judgment of the board of directors. Text A. Unless an e lection to purchase has been filed under § 13.1-749.1, a court in a judicial proceeding brought to dissolve a corporation may appoint one or more receivers to wind up and liquidate, or one or more custodians to manage while the proceeding is pending, the business and affairs of the corporation. The court shall hold a hearing, after notifying all parties to the proceeding and any interested persons designated by the court, before appointing a receiver or custodian. The court appointing a receiver or c ustodian has exclusive jurisdiction over the corporation and all its property wherever located. B. The court m ay appoint as a receiver or custodian an individual, a domestic corporation or eligible entity, or a foreign corporation or eligible entity authorized to transact business in the Commonwealth. The court may require the receiver or custodian to post bond, with or without sureties, in an amount the court directs. C. The court s hall describe the powers and duties of the receiver or custodian in its appointing order, which may be amended from time to time. Among other powers: 1. The r eceiver (i) may dispose of all or any part of the assets of the corporation wherever located, at a public or private sale; and (ii) may sue and defend in the receivers own name as receiver of the corporation in all courts of the Commonwealth; and 2. The custodian may exercise all of the powers of the corporation, through or in place of its board of directors or officers, to the extent necessary to manage the affairs of the corpora tion in the best interest of its shareholders and creditors. D. The court d uring a receivership may redesignate the receiver a custodian, and during a custodianship may redesignate the custodian a receiver. E. The court f rom time to time during the receivership or custodianship may order compensation paid and expenses paid or reimbursed to the receiver or custodian from the assets of the corporation or proceeds from the sale of the assets. History History. Code 1950, §§ 13.1-94 to 13.1-96; 1956, c. 428; 1959, Ex. S ess., c. 57; 1968, c. 112; 1974, c. 291; 1975, c. 500; 1985, c. 522; 2005, c. 765; 2007, c. 165; 2019, c. 734. Annotations The 2005 amendments. The 2005 amendment by c. 765 substituted the Commonwealth for this Commonwealth in subsection B and subdivision C 1; and substituted the custo dians for his in subsection E. The 2007 amendments. The 2007 amendment by c. 165 added Unless an election to purchase has been filed under § 13.1-749.1 at the beginning of subsection A. The 2019 amendments. The 2019 amendment by c. 734, in subsection B, inserted as a receiver or custodian following may appoint, inserted or eligible entity foll owing corporation twice, and deleted as a receiver or custodian preceding The court; in subdivision C 1, deleted if authorized by the court following sale, and substituted the receivers for his; in subsection D, deleted if doing so is in the best interest of the corporation, its shareholders, and creditors at the end; in subsection E, substituted expenses paid or reimbursed for expense disbursements or reimbursements made,  and deleted and the custodians counsel; and made stylistic changes. Law Review. For 2007 annual survey article, Corporate and Business Law, see 42 U. Rich. L. Rev. 273 (2007). Michies Jurisprudence. For related discussion, see 15 M.J. Receivers, §§ 12, 22.

Text A. If after a hearing the court determines that one or more grounds for judicial dissolution described in § 13.1-747 exist, it may enter a decree directing that the corporation shall be dissolved. The clerk of the court shall deliver a certified copy of the decree to the Commission, which shall enter an order of involuntary dissolution. B. After the o rder of involuntary dissolution has been entered, the court shall direct the winding up and liquidation of the corporations business and affairs in accordance with § 13.1-745 and the notification of claimants in accordance with §§ 13.1-746, 13.1-746.1, and 13.1-746.2. When all of the assets of the corporation have been distributed to its creditors and shareholders, the court shall so advise the Commission, which shall enter an order of termination of corporate existence. History History. Code 1950, § 13.1-99; 1956, c. 428; 1985, c. 522; 2005, c. 765 . Annotations The 2005 amendments. The 2005 amendment by c. 765, in the second sentence of subsection B, inserted 13.1-746.1, and 13.1-746.2 and made a minor stylistic change. Michies Jurisprudence. For related discussion, see 4B M.J. Corporations, § 264. § 13.1-749.1. Election to purchase in lieu of dissolution. Text A. Unless othe rwise provided in the articles of incorporation, in a proceeding under subdivision A 1 of § 13.1-747 to dissolve a corporation, the corporation may elect or, if it fails to elect, one or more shareholders may elect to purchase all shares owned by the petitioning shareholder at the fair value of the shares. An election pursuant to this section shall be irrevocable unless the court determines that it is equitable to set aside or modify the election. B. An election to purchase pursuant to this section may be filed with the court at any time within 90 days after the filing of the petition under subdivision A 1 of § 13.1-747 or at such later time as the court in its discretion may allow. If the election to purcha se is filed by one or more shareholders, the corporation shall, within 10 days thereafter, give written notice to all shareholders, other than the petitioner. The notice shall state the name and number of shares owned by the petitioner and the name and n umber of shares owned by each electing shareholder and shall advise the recipients of their right to join in the election to purchase shares in accordance with this section. Shareholders who wish to participate shall file notice of their intention to joi n in the purchase no later than 30 days after the effectiveness of the notice to them. All shareholders who have filed an election or notice of their intention to participate in the election to purchase thereby become parties to the proceeding and shall participate in the purchase in proportion to their ownership of outstanding shares as of the date the first election was filed, unless they otherwise agree or the court otherwise directs. After an election has been filed by the corporation or one or more shareholders, the proceeding under subdivision A 1 of § 13.1-747 may not be discontinued or settled, nor may the petitioning shareholder sell or otherwise dispose of the petitioners shares, unless the court determines that it would be equitable t o the corporation and the shareholders, other than the petitioner, to permit such discontinuance, settlement, sale, or other disposition. C. If, within 60 days of the filing of the first election, the parties reach agreement as to the fair value and terms of purchase of the petitioners shares, the court shall enter an order directing the purchase of petitioners shares upon the terms and conditio ns agreed to by the parties. D. If the part ies are unable to reach an agreement as provided for in subsection C, the court, upon application of any party, shall stay the proceedings under subdivision A 1 of § 13.1-747 and determine the fair value of the petitioners shares as of the day bef ore the date on which the petition under subdivision A 1 of § 13.1-747 was filed or as of such other date as the court deems appropriate under the circumstances. The determination of fair value shall include consideration of all relevant facts and cir cumstances, including, unless the court determines it would be unjust or inequitable to do so, (i) the petitioners minority status, (ii) the marketability of the petitioners shares, (iii) the relevant terms of any shareholders agreement, and (iv) if the court finds that the value of the corporation has been diminished by the wrongful conduct of controlling shareholders, the petitioners proportionate claim for any compensable corporate injury. In determining the fair value, the court may, in its discretion, select an appraiser to appraise the fair value of the petitioners shares and shall assess the cost of any such appraisal to the parties, to the corporation, or both, as the equities may appear to the court. E. Upon determ ining the fair value of the shares, the court shall enter an order directing the purchase upon such terms and conditions as the court deems appropriate, which may include payment of the purchase price in installments, where necessary in the interests of equity, provision for security to assure payment of the purchase price and any additional costs, fees and expenses as may have been awarded, and, if the shares are to be purchased by shareholders, the allocation of shares among them. In allocating petiti oners shares among holders of different classes of shares, the court should attempt to preserve the existing distribution of voting rights among holders of different classes insofar as practicable and may direct that holders of a specific class or cl asses shall not participate in the purchase. Interest may be allowed at the rate and from the date determined by the court to be equitable, but if the court finds that the refusal of the petitioning shareholder to accept an offer of payment was arbitrary or otherwise not in good faith, no interest shall be allowed. If the court finds that the petitioning shareholder had probable grounds for relief under subdivision A 1 b or d of § 13.1-747, it may award expenses to the petitioning shareholder. F. Upon entry of an order under subsection C or E, the court shall dismiss the petition to dissolve the corporation under subdivision A 1 of § 13.1-747 and the petitioning shareholder shall no longer have any rights or status as a shareholder of the corporation, ex cept the right to receive the amounts awarded to him by the order of the court, which shall be enforceable in the same manner as any other judgment. G. The purchas e ordered pursuant to subsection E shall be made within 10 days after the date the order becomes final. H. Any payment by the corporation pursuant to an order under subsection C or E, other than an award of expenses pursuant to subsection E, is subject to the provisions of § 13.1-653. History History. 2005, c. 765; 2007, c. 165; 2012, c. 706; 2015, c. 611; 2019, c. 734. Annotations The 2007 amendments. The 2007 amendment by c. 165 deleted that is not a public corporation following to dissolve a corporation in subsection A and substituted and shall advise for and must advise in the third sentence of subsection B. The 2012 amendments. The 2012 amendment by c. 706 rewrote subsection G. The 2015 amendments. The 2015 amendment by c. 611 added the second sentence of subsection D. The 2019 amendments. The 2019 amendment by c. 734, in subsection B, substituted effectiveness for effective date, and inserted outstanding following owners hip of; in subsection E, inserted expenses following may award, and deleted reasonable fees and expenses of counsel and of any experts employed by the shareholder at the end; and in subsection H, deleted fees and prece ding expenses. Law Review. For survey article, Corporate and Business Law, see 48 U. Rich. L. Rev. 39 (2013). CIRCUIT COURT OPINIONS Stay for additional discovery.  Because the only issue to determine was the fair value of a shareholders shares, and because the corporation had provided and would continue to provide inform ation that related to its value, it would be meaningless to vacate an order granting a stay under § 13.1-749.1 to permit the shareholder unrestricted discovery. Hartley v. Marco Invs., Inc., 82 Va. Cir. 294, 2011 Va. Cir. LEXIS 174 (Norfolk Feb. 24, 2 011). Valuation date.  In a case in which defendant and plaintiff were 50% shareholders in a corporation, the court found that the statutory valuation date of August 1, 2019, was both e quitable and appropriate because plaintiffs alleged actions since she filed for dissolution  even if they damaged the corporation  would not make the August 1, 2019, valuation date inequitable, and any alternative valuation date at the curren t stage in the litigation would be unduly burdensome; defendant had not proposed an alternative valuation date; and the April 16, 2020, order directed that plaintiff would be held liable to the corporation for any harm she caused the corporation since Se ptember 2019. Biton v. Kreinis, 105 Va. Cir. 86, 2020 Va. Cir. LEXIS 69 (Norfolk May 1, 2020). Fair value determination.  Court did not err in finding the fair value of the companys equity using the discounted cash method was $532,582 and that plaintiffs shares were valued at $177,530 because application of the marketability discount would be unjust and inequitable as plaintiff established oppressive conduct by defendant and the third shareholder, and plaintiff should not receive less than the fair value of his shares simply where defendant elected to purchase plaintiffs shares in lieu of the corporate dissolution; and because the value of the corporation had not been diminished by the controlling shareholders. Jones v. A Town Smoke House & Catering Inc., 106 Va. Cir. 1 68, 2020 Va. Cir. LEXIS 478 (Waynesboro Oct. 19, 2020). Payment plan for election to purchase.  Based on the evidence, the court found that, in th...

akn:section.akn:heading: Articles of termination of corporate existence

akn:content.akn:p: Text A. When a corp oration has distributed all of its assets to its creditors and shareholders and voluntary dissolution proceedings have not been revoked, it shall deliver to the Commission for filing articles of termination of corporate existence. The articles shall set forth: 1. The n ame of the corporation; 2. That all the assets of the corporation have been distributed to its creditors and shareholders; and 3. That the dissolution of the corporation has not been revoked. B. With the ar ticles of termination of corporate existence, the corporation shall file a statement certifying that the corporation has filed returns and has paid all state taxes to the time of the statement. In contemplation of submitting the required statement, the c orporation may file returns and pay taxes before such returns and taxes would otherwise be due. C. If the Comm ission finds that the articles of termination of corporate existence comply with the requirements of law and that all required fees have been paid, it shall by order issue a certificate of termination of corporate existence. When the certificate is effec tive, the existence of the corporation shall cease, except for the purpose of suits, other proceedings and appropriate corporate action by shareholders, directors and officers as provided in this chapter. D. The stateme nt that all the assets of the corporation have been distributed to its creditors and shareholders means that the corporation has divested itself of all its assets by the payment of claims or liquidating dividends or by assignment to a trustee or trustees for the benefit of claimants or shareholders. If any shareholder, certificate holder, member, bondholder, or other security holder, or a participating patron of a cooperative who is entitled to a share in the distribution of the assets cannot be found, the corporation may thereupon, and without awaiting the one year mentioned in § 55.1-2513, pay such persons share to the State Treasurer as abandoned property on complying with all applicable requirements of § 55.1-2524 except subdivisi on B 4. History History. Code 1950, § 13.1-89; 1956, c. 428; 1966, c. 343; 1975, c. 500 ; 1985, c. 522; 1994, c. 291; 2004, c. 162; 2005, c. 765; 2019, c. 734. Annotations Editors note. To conform to the recodification of Title 55 by Acts 2019, c. 712, effective October 1, 2019, the following substitutions were made at the direction of the Virgin ia Code Commission: substituted 55.1-2513 for 55-210.7 and 55.1-2524 for 55-210.12. The 2004 amendments. The 2004 amendment by c. 162 substituted shareholder, certificate holder, member, bondholder, or other security holder, or a participating patron of a coopera tive for person described in § 55-210.6 in the last sentence of subsection D. The 2005 amendments. The 2005 amendment by c. 765 substituted subdivision B 4 for subdivision 4 of subsection B of that section in subsection D. The 2019 amendments. The 2019 amendment by c. 734, in subsection A, substituted deliver to the Commission for filing for file, and deleted with the Commission following existence; in subsection B, substituted statement for certificate; and in subsection C, substituted When the certificate is effective for Upon the issuance of such certificate.

akn:section.akn:heading: Termination of corporate existence by incorporators or initial directors

akn:content.akn:p: Text A majority of the initial directors, or, if initial directors were not named in the articles of incorporation and have not been elected, a majority of the incorporators of a corporation that has not issued shares or has not commenced business may dissolve the corporation and terminate its corporate existence by filing with the Commission articles of termination of corporate existence that set forth: 1. The n ame of the corporation; 2. The date of its incorporation; 3. Either (i) that none of the corporations shares have been issued or (ii) that the corporation has not commenced business; 4. That no debt of the corporation remains unpaid; 5. That the net assets of the corporation remaining after winding up have been distributed to the shareholders, if shares were issued; and 6. That a majority of the initial directors authorized the dissolution or that initial directors were not named in the articles of incorporation and have not been elected and a majority o f the incorporators authorized the dissolution. History History. Code 1950, § 13.1-79; 1956, c. 428; 1975, c. 500; 1985, c. 522 ; 1986, c. 234; 2019, c. 734. Annotations The 2019 amendments. The 2019 amendment by c. 734, in the first paragraph, inserted a majority of following been elected; and rewrote subdivision 2, which was formerly repealed. CASE NOTES Constitutionality.  The form and wisdom of the method of voluntary surrender of corporate franchises are matters which are expressly delegated to the legislature by the terms of the Constitution, and as to them neither the Corporation Commission nor the Supreme Court can have any controlling voice. Jeffries v. Commonwealth, 121 Va. 425, 93 S.E. 701, 1917 Va. LEXIS 48 (1917) (decided under prior law).

Text A. If any dome stic corporation fails to file its annual report or pay its annual registration fee in a timely manner as required by this chapter, the Commission shall mail to each such corporation a notice of the impending termination of its corporate existence. Wheth er or not such notice is mailed, if any corporation fails to file its annual report or pay its annual registration fee on or before the last day of the fourth month immediately following its annual report or annual registration fee due date each year, th e corporate existence of the corporation shall be automatically terminated as of that day. B. If any dome stic corporation whose registered agent has filed with the Commission a statement of resignation pursuant to § 13.1-636 fails to file a statement of change pursuant to § 13.1-635 within 31 days after the date on which the statement of resignation w as filed, the Commission shall mail notice to the corporation of the impending termination of its corporate existence. If the corporation fails to file the statement of change before the last day of the second month immediately following the month in whi ch the impending termination notice was mailed, the corporate existence of the corporation shall be automatically terminated as of that day. C. The propert ies and affairs of a corporation whose corporate existence has been terminated pursuant to this section shall pass automatically to its directors as trustees in liquidation. The trustees shall then proceed to (i) collect the assets of the corporation, (i i) sell, convey, and dispose of such of its properties that are not to be distributed in kind to its shareholders, (iii) pay, satisfy, and discharge its liabilities and obligations, and (iv) do all other acts required to liquidate its business and affair s. After paying or adequately providing for the payment of all its obligations, the trustees shall distribute the remainder of its assets, either in cash or in kind, among its shareholders according to their respective rights and interests. D. No officer, director, or agent of a corporation shall have any personal obligation for any of the liabilities of the corporation whether such liabilities arise in contract, tort, or otherwise, solely by reason of the termination of the corporations existence pu rsuant to this section. History History. Code 1950, § 13.1-91; 1956, c. 428; 1970, c. 4; 1974, c. 72; 1 975, c. 500; 1985, cc. 522, 528; 1987, c. 2; 1988, c. 405; 1991, c. 125; 1997, c. 216; 2000, c. 52; 2005, c. 765; 2010, c. 753. Annotations Editors note. Acts 2000, c. 52, which added subsection C, in cl. 2 provides: That the provisions of this act shall apply to any domestic or foreign corporation, domestic or foreign limited liability company, or domestic or foreign limited partnership whose registered agent files a certificate of resignation with the State Corporation Commission pursuant to §§ 13.1-636, 13.1-765, 13.1-835, 13.1-927, 13.1-1017, or § 50-73.6 of the Code of Virginia on or after January 1, 2001. The 1997 amendment, effective January 1, 1998, in the second sentence of subsection A, substituted the last day of the fourth month immediately following its annual report due date each year for September 1 of the year it is due and substituted as of that day for as of September 1; in subdivision B 1, substituted the corporations annual report due date determined in accordance with subsection C of § 13.1-775 for April 1 (following the January assessment) i n the first sentence and substituted after such date for after April 1 in the second sentence; and, in subdivision B 2, substituted the due date for June 1 in the first sentence and substituted the last day of the four th month immediately following the due date for September 1 in the second sentence. The 2000 amendments. The 2000 amendment by c. 52 added subsection C. For applicability, see editors note. The 2005 amendments. The 2005 amendment by c. 765 substituted shareholders for stockholders in the third and fourth sentences of subdivision B 2; and in subsection C, substituted a statement for his statement and deleted of this section following B 2; and made minor stylistic changes. The 2010 amendments. The 2010 amendment by c. 753 rewrote the section. Law Review. For 1987 survey of Virginia business and corporate law, see 21 U. Rich. L. Rev. 645 (1987). For an article, Corporate and Business Law, see 32 U. Rich. L. Rev. 1067 (1998). CASE NOTES Effect of termination of corporate existence.  A corporate dissolution (now termination of corporate existence), by operation of law, under this unique Virginia statute, has the legal effect of causing a de jure dissolution (now termination of corporate existence) of the corporation as opposed to a de facto dissolution (now termination of corporate existence), because the statute declares a corporation thus delinquent shall ipso facto cease to exist. Moore v. Occupational Safety & Health Review Comm'n, 591 F.2d 991, 1979 U.S. App. LEXIS 17157 (4th Cir. 1979) (decided under prior law). Under this section, an automatic dissolution (now termination of corporate existence) works a forfeiture of the corporate charter by operation of law, thereby stripping the corporations legal mandate to exist. Moore v. Occupational Safety & Health Review Comm'n, 591 F.2d 991, 1979 U.S. App. LEXIS 17157 (4th Cir. 1979) (decided unde r prior law). If a Virginia corporation fails to pay its annual registration fee by September 1, the corporation is automatically terminated. An automatic dissolution under thi s section works a forfeiture of the corporate charter by operation of law, thereby stripping the corporations legal mandate to exist. A dissolved domestic corporation is no corporation at all. Hudgins v. IRS, 132 Bankr. 115, 1991 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 102 02 (E.D. Va. 1991), aff'd, 967 F.2d 973, 1992 U.S. App. LEXIS 14136 (4th Cir. 1992). Upon dissolution directors become trustees of corporate assets.  Upon dissolution, the directors no longer function as directors of a corporation. This section provides that they become trustees in dissolution. The assets of th e corporation automatically pass to them in their new capacity. This is the res of the trust they must administer. Flip Mtg. Corp. v. McElhone, 841 F.2d 531, 1988 U.S. App. LEXIS 2831 (4th Cir. 1988). Under the Virginia Code, when a corporation is terminated for failure to pay its annual registration fees, the assets of the corporation pass to the directors as trustees in liquidation. The trustees are charged with disposing of the corporate assets, discharging the corporations debts, and distributing the remainder of the assets to the shareholders. The debts referred to by this section are the pre-existing debts of the corporation. Hudgins v. IRS, 132 Bankr. 115, 1991 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 10202 (E.D. Va. 1991), aff'd, 967 F.2d 973, 1992 U.S. App. LEXIS 14136 (4th Cir. 1992). Directors liability.  People dealing with a corporation are obliged to look to the corporation for satisfaction of their claims; only in extraordinary circumstances are directors liabl e for corporate debts and this section and § 13.1-754 must be construed in a manner consistent with the strong public policy of shielding directors from individual liability for corporate debt and these sections do not impose any liability for corpora te debt on the directors simply because the corporation has been automatically dissolved. Even after dissolution, the directors are shielded from individual liability if they discharge the duties the statute places on them to marshal assets, pay pre-exis ting debts, and distribute the remaining funds, if any, to the shareholders. Moreover, the directors may temporarily continue the corporate business as an incident to its liquidation without incurring individual liability. The directors difficulty ar ises when they violate the law and carry on the business instead of liquidating it. They then become personally liable. Flip Mtg. Corp. v. McElhone, 841 F.2d 531, 1988 U.S. App. LEXIS 2831 (4th Cir. 1988). Liability of directors and officers for actions taken after termination of corporate existence.  Upon a corporations dissolution (now termination of corporate existence) by operation of law under this section, there is no corporation at all, and any actio ns performed by the directors or officers not looking to the dissolution (now termination of corporate existence) of the corporation should be deemed individual actions with concomitant individual liability therefor. Moore v. Occupational Safety & Health Review Comm'n, 591 F.2d 991, 1979 U.S. App. LEXIS 17157 (4th Cir. 1979) (decided under prior law). Any actions performed by the directors or officers after dissolution, if not related to the process of winding up the corporations affairs, should be deemed i ndividual actions, with concomitant individual liability therefor. If an entity is no corporation at all, the individuals who conduct its affairs must be personally liable for their acts. Hudgins v. IRS, 132 Bankr. 115, 1991 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 10202 (E.D. Va. 1991), aff'd, 967 F.2d 973, 1992 U.S. App. LEXIS 14136 (4th Cir. 1992). This section, the Virginia corporate dissolution (now termination of corporate existence) statute, by its terms requires a finding of personal responsibility on t he part of the corporate directors for any liability created by any normal continuance of the corporate business after dissolution (now termination of corporate existence). Moore v. Occupational Safety & Health Review Comm'n, 591 F.2d 991, 1979 U.S. App. LEXIS 17157 (4th Cir. 1979) (decided under prior law). District court erred in dismissing lessors claim for breach of fiduciary duty for conduct engaged in before January 1, 2000; the directors duties as trust ees in liquidation attached only upon termination of the corporate existence. Orix Credit Alliance, Inc. v. Young Express, Inc., 43 Fed. Appx. 650, 2002 U.S. ...

Text A. The corpora te existence of a corporation may be terminated involuntarily by order of the Commission when it finds that the corporation (i) has continued to exceed or abuse the authority conferred upon it by law; (ii) has failed to maintain a registered office or a registered agent in this Commonwealth as required by law; (iii) has failed to file any document required by this chapter to be filed with the Commission; or (iv) has been convicted for a violation of 8 U.S.C. § 1324a(f), as amended, for actions of its officers and directors constituting a pattern or practice of employing unauthorized aliens in the Commonwealth. Upon termination, the properties and affairs of the corporation shall pass automatically to its directors as trustees in liquidation. The tru stees then shall proceed to collect the assets of the corporation; sell, convey and dispose of such of its properties as are not to be distributed in kind to its shareholders; pay, satisfy and discharge its liabilities and obligations; and do all other a cts required to liquidate its business and affairs. After paying or adequately providing for the payment of all its obligations, the trustees shall distribute the remainder of its assets, either in cash or in kind, among its shareholders according to the ir respective rights and interests. A corporation whose existence is terminated pursuant to clause (iv) shall not be eligible for reinstatement for a period of not less than one year. B. Any corpora tion convicted of the offense listed in clause (iv) of subsection A shall immediately report such conviction to the Commission and file with the Commission an authenticated copy of the judgment or record of conviction. C. Before ente ring any such order the Commission shall issue a rule against the corporation giving it an opportunity to be heard and show cause why such an order should not be entered. The Commission may issue the rule on its own motion or on motion of the Attorney Ge neral. History History. Code 1950, § 13.1-93; 1956, c. 428; 1958, c. 506; 1968, c. 116 ; 1975, cc. 88, 500; 1985, c. 522; 1991, c. 310; 2008, cc. 588, 770. Annotations The 2008 amendments. The 2008 amendments by cc. 588 and 770 are identical, and in subsection A, inserted clause (iv), added the last sentence, and made related changes; added subsecti on B; and redesignated former subsection B as subsection C. CASE NOTES Editors note. Some of the cases below were decided under prior law. How forfei ture of corporate franchise can be effected.  The forfeiture of corporate franchises can be effected only by the State or private persons under statutory authority. Elliott's Knob Iron, Steel & Coal Co. v. SC C, 123 Va. 63, 96 S.E. 353, 1918 Va. LEXIS 6 (1918). Cannot be done collaterally.  A cause of forfeiture of the charter of a corporation, however great, cannot be taken advantage of collaterally or incidentally or in any other mode than by a dir ect proceeding for that purpose on behalf of the government. Pixley v. Roanoke Nav. Co., 75 Va. 320, 1881 Va. LEXIS 16 (1881); Dismal Swamp R.R. v. John L. Roper Lumber Co., 114 Va. 537, 77 S.E. 598, 1913 Va. LEXIS 115 (1913) (see Colonial Inv. Co. v. Ch errydale Cement Block Co., 194 Va. 454, 73 S.E.2d 419 (1952)). Applicable to any corporation whose activities are outside its charter.  This section is simply the statutory mechanism by which the Attorney General initiates Commission revocation of the charter of any corporation which has abused th e Commonwealths permission to use the corporate form of doing business for purposes set forth in that charter. The provision applies with equal force to any corporation whose activities are outside the permissible ambit of its charter. Croatan Books, Inc. v. Virginia, 574 F. Supp. 880, 1983 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 11993 (E.D. Va. 1983), dismissed, 583 F. Supp. 857, 1984 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 18236 (E.D. Va. 1984). Distribution of obscene materials.  Obscene material enjoys no protection under U.S. Const., Amend. I. Therefore, in no way could a corporation claim that the Commonwealth authorized it to purvey ob scene materials by allowing it to distribute novelties, magazines, books and newspapers. Clearly, in excess of 60 felony convictions for doing so could reasonably be considered an abuse of its charter. Croatan Books, Inc. v. Virginia, 574 F. Supp. 880, 1 983 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 11993 (E.D. Va. 1983), dismissed, 583 F. Supp. 857, 1984 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 18236 (E.D. Va. 1984). CIRCUIT COURT OPINIONS Transfer of stock after termination.  Decedent had the right to transfer 100 shares of stock to his son even though the corporations existence had been terminated where, under subsection A of § 13.1-753, it appeared that the decedent had an expectation of future distribution, and there was no evidence that the corporations articles of incorporation, bylaws, or agreement restricted the transfer of shares. Square Deal Demolition, Inc. v. Dox ie, 74 Va. Cir. 441, 2008 Va. Cir. LEXIS 65 (Norfolk Jan. 10, 2008).

akn:section.akn:heading: Reinstatement of a corporation that has ceased to exist

akn:content.akn:p: Text A. A corporati on that has ceased to exist pursuant to this article may apply to the Commission for reinstatement within five years thereafter unless the corporate existence was terminated by order of the Commission (i) upon a finding that the corporation has continued to exceed or abuse the authority conferred upon it by law or (ii) entered pursuant to § 13.1-749 and the circuit courts decree directing dissolution contains no provision for reinstatement of corporate existence. B. To have its corporate existence reinstated, the corporation shall provide the Commission with the following: 1. An ap plication for reinstatement, which shall include the identification number issued by the Commission to the corporation, and which may be in the form of a letter signed by an officer or director of the corporation, or which may be by affidavit signed by a n agent of any shareholders interests stating that after diligent search by such agent, no officer or director can be found; 2. A reinstatement fee of $100; 3. All annual registration fees and penalties that were due before the corporation ceased to exist and that would have been assessed or imposed to the date of reinstatement if the corpora tions existence had not been terminated; 4. An annual report for the calendar year that corresponds to the calendar year of the latest annual registration fee that was assessed or that would have been assessed to the date of rei nstatement; 5. If the name of the corporation does not comply with the provisions of § 13.1-630 at the time of reinstatement, articles of amendment to the articles of incorporation to change the c orporations name to a name that satisfies the provisions of § 13.1-630, with the fee required by this chapter for the filing of articles of amendment; and 6. If the corporations registered agent has filed a statement of resignation and a new registered agent has not been appointed, a statement of change pursuant to § 13.1-635. C. If the corp oration complies with the provisions of this section, the Commission shall enter an order of reinstatement of corporate existence. Upon entry of the order, the corporate existence shall be deemed to have continued from the date of termination as if the t ermination had never occurred, and any liability incurred by the corporation or a director, officer, or other agent after the termination and before the reinstatement is determined as if the termination of the corporations existence had never occurre d. History History. Code 1950, § 13.1-92; 1956, c. 428; 1958, c. 564; 1975, c. 88; 1978, c. 804; 1980, c. 654; 1982, c. 648; 1984, c. 69; 1985, c. 522; 1986, c. 234; 1988, c. 405; 2004, c. 601; 2005, c. 379; 2006, c. 663; 2015, c. 623. Annotations The 2004 amendments. The 2004 amendment by c. 601 substituted and any liability incurred by the corporation or a director, officer, or other agent after termination of corporate e xistence and before the reinstatement shall be determined as if the termination of corporate existence had never occurred for except that reinstatement shall have no effect on any question of personal liability of the directors, officers or agent s in respect to the period between termination of corporate existence and reinstatement in the next-to-last sentence. The 2005 amendments. The 2005 amendment by c. 379, effective March 21, 2005, in the last sentence, substituted is not distinguishable upon the records of the Commission, for has been assumed or reserved or registered by any other person and added to a name that is distinguishable upon the records of the Commission. The 2006 amendments. The 2006 amendment by c. 663 inserted the clause (i) designation and added clause (ii). The 2015 amendments. The 2015 amendment by c. 623 rewrote the section. Michies Jurisprudence. For related discussion, see 4B M.J. Corporations, § 275. CASE NOTES Legislative intent.  The legislature intended that once a corporation achieves reinstatement, its corporate status relates back to the date of its termination and it is as if the corp oration had never been terminated and debtors action to achieve reinstatement after the filing of the petition for Chapter 11 supports its eligibility for Chapter 11 relief since, in the eyes of the State, it has been a corporation all along. In re W ine Farms, Inc., 94 Bankr. 410, 1988 Bankr. LEXIS 2188 (Bankr. W.D. Va. 1988). Directors liability.  People dealing with a corporation are obliged to look to the corporation for satisfaction of their claims and only in extraordinary circumstances are directors li able for corporate debts. Section 13.1-752 and this section must be construed in a manner consistent with the strong public policy of shielding directors from individual liability for corporate debt and these sections do not impose any liability for corp orate debt on the directors simply because the corporation has been automatically dissolved. Even after dissolution, the directors are shielded from individual liability if they discharge the duties the statute places on them to marshal assets, pay pre-e xisting debts, and distribute the remaining funds, if any, to the shareholders. Moreover, the directors may temporarily continue the corporate business as an incident to its liquidation without incurring individual liability. The directors difficulty arises when they violate the law and carry on the business instead of liquidating it. They then become personally liable. Flip Mtg. Corp. v. McElhone, 841 F.2d 531, 1988 U.S. App. LEXIS 2831 (4th Cir. 1988). Liability of directors for actions taken between termination of corporate existence and reinstatement.  This section, the Virginia reinstatement statute, does not relieve the directors, who have continued the corporate business, of individual liability for actions i n the interim period between dissolution (now termination of corporate existence) and reinstatement. Moore v. Occupational Safety & Health Review Comm'n, 591 F.2d 991, 1979 U.S. App. LEXIS 17157 (4th Cir. 1979) (decided under prior law). In an action for damages by an information technology company and its sole owner against a former partner, his wife, and their new corporation, the trial court di d not err in refusing to strike all of plaintiffs evidence because the information technology companys corporate existence was terminated during the time of the alleged wrong where the companys reinstatement following termination had the retr oactive effect of placing it in a position as if its termination had never occurred. Syed v. Zh Techs., Inc., 280 Va. 58, 694 S.E.2d 625, 2010 Va. LEXIS 73 (2010). Directors, etc., not relieved of liability by reinstatement.  Language of this section, the Virginia reinstatement statute, is quite clear that reinstatement has no effect on any question of personal liability of the directo rs. Moore v. Occupational Safety & Health Review Comm'n, 591 F.2d 991, 1979 U.S. App. LEXIS 17157 (4th Cir. 1979) (decided under prior law). This section makes the revived corporation liable for any liabilities incurred in the interim period, but it declares at the same time, in unmistakable terms, tha t reinstatement will not relieve the directors of the personal liability they have already incurred by continuing the normal operations of the corporation during dissolution. Moore v. Occupational Safety & Health Review Comm'n, 591 F.2d 991, 1979 U.S. Ap p. LEXIS 17157 (4th Cir. 1979) (decided under prior law). Under § 13.1-752 and this section, the managing officers and directors of a corporation incurred personal liability as employers under the federal Occu pational Safety and Health Act (29 U.S.C. § 651 et seq.) for violations between the dates of the corporations dissolution under § 13.1-752 and reinstatement under this section, and for the penalty assessed because of such violations, and the su bsequent reinstatement of the corporate charter did not relieve them of such liability. Moore v. Occupational Safety & Health Review Comm'n, 591 F.2d 991, 1979 U.S. App. LEXIS 17157 (4th Cir. 1979) (decided under prior law). Where a party alleges that the business affairs of a dissolved corporation have been carried on by the acts of certain officers, directors, or agents of the disso lved corporation, then those officers, directors, or agents can be held personally liable for contracts entered on behalf of the dissolved corporation. Any such personal liability incurred because of acts done during the period of corporate dissolution i s not relieved by the reinstatement of the corporation. McLean Bank v. Nelson, 232 Va. 420, 350 S.E.2d 651, 3 Va. Law Rep. 1423, 1986 Va. LEXIS 274 (1986). Upon dissolution directors become trustees of corporate assets.  Upon dissolution, the directors no longer function as directors of a corporation and § 13.1-752 provides that they become trustees in dissolution, the assets o f the corporation automatically pass to them in their new capacity and this is the res of the trust they must administer. Flip Mtg. Corp. v. McElhone, 841 F.2d 531, 1988 U.S. App. LEXIS 2831 (4th Cir. 1988). Burden on directors as trustees to produce accurate accounts of assets and affairs of trust created by § 13.1-752 and to prove any charges or other debts which they wish to advance to limit their liability. Flip Mtg. Corp. v. McElhone, 841 F.2d 531, 1988 U.S. App. LEXIS 2831 (4th Cir. 1988). When they breach their fiduciary duties as trustees directors incur personal liability to beneficiaries of trust created by § 13.1-752 and this section provides that such liability, once incurred, is not discharged by the reinstatement of the corporation. Defendants breached their fiduciary duties, by using the trust res for operation o f the business in violation of the statute instead of paying pre-existing obligations owed and for that reason they were personally liable for the damages caused by their breach of trust. Flip Mtg. Corp. v. McElhone, 841 F.2d 531, 1988 U.S. App. LEXIS 28 31...

akn:section.akn:heading: Survival of remedy after termination of corporate existence

akn:content.akn:p: Text The termination of corporate existence shall not take away or impair any remedy available to or against the corporation or its directors, officers, or shareholders for any right or claim existing or any liability incurred prior to such termination. Any such action or proceeding by or against the corporation may be prosecuted or defended by the corporation in its corporate name. The shareholders, directors, and officers shall have power to take such corporate or other action as shall be appropriate to protect such remedy, right, or claim. History History. Code 1950, § 13.1-101; 1956, c. 428; 1985, c. 522; 2019, c. 73 4. Annotations The 2019 amendments. The 2019 amendment by c. 734 made stylistic changes. Law Review. For article surveying major developments between 1991 and 1992 that affect business and corporate law in Virginia, see Business and Corporate Law, 26 U. R ich. L. Rev. 653 (1992). Michies Jurisprudence. For related discussion, see 1A M.J. Abatement, Survival and Revival, § 16; 2C M.J. Ba nkruptcy, § 12; 4B M.J. Corporations, §§ 35, 262, 276, 277. CASE NOTES Editors note. Some of the cases below were decided under prior law. Liberal construction.  The simplification of procedures and the complete reversal of the common-law rule of abatement of actions upon dissolution (now termination of corporate existence ) are remedial measures entitled to a liberal construction to effectuate their purposes. United States v. Village Corp., 298 F.2d 816, 1962 U.S. App. LEXIS 6290 (4th Cir. 1962). Strict construction.  Under the common law, once a corporations existence was terminated, its capacity to sue, or to be sued, likewise was terminated, irrespective of when the caus e of action arose. This section, however, partially changed the common-law rule. This section, being in derogation of the common law, therefore, must be strictly construed. Harris v. T.I., Inc., 243 Va. 63, 413 S.E.2d 605, 8 Va. Law Rep. 1751, 1992 Va. L EXIS 149 (1992). Ap plication of Virginia statutes to foreign corporations.  As to application to foreign corporations of former § 13-70, providing for continuation of corporate existence for three years following dissolution of a corpo ration for the purpose of winding up its affairs, and former § 13-72, providing that dissolution (now termination of corporate existence) of a corporation should not abate any pending action against it, see Bardach Iron & Steel Co. v. Tenenbaum, 136 V a. 163, 118 S.E. 502, 1923 Va. LEXIS 76 (1923); DuPont Eng'r Co. v. John P. Harvey Constr. Co., 156 Va. 582, 158 S.E. 891, 1931 Va. LEXIS 214 (1931). Section authorizes suits by or against corporation without limitation of time.  This section authorizes actions by or against a corporation, and in its corporate name, after dissolution (now termination of corporate existence) without a limit ation of time. United States v. Village Corp., 298 F.2d 816, 1962 U.S. App. LEXIS 6290 (4th Cir. 1962). Under this section, passage of time after the date of dissolution (now termination of corporate existence) is without significance, although general statutes of l imitation referable to the accrual of the cause of action remain applicable. United States v. Village Corp., 298 F.2d 816, 1962 U.S. App. LEXIS 6290 (4th Cir. 1962). And applies to corporations whose charters were revoked prior to its enactment.  This section applied to suits against corporations the charters of which had been revoked prior to the enactment of this section. United States v. Village Corp., 298 F.2d 816, 1962 U.S. App. LEXIS 6290 (4th Cir. 1962). There was no retroactivity in the application of this section to corporations the charter of which had been revoked prior to the enactment of the section. It alte red no substantive right; it only altered the procedure by which substantive rights may be judicially enforced. United States v. Village Corp., 298 F.2d 816, 1962 U.S. App. LEXIS 6290 (4th Cir. 1962). Court order continuing authority of directors or appointing receiver is no longer necessary.  Under this section a court order continuing the authority of directors or appointing a receiver is no longer a prerequisite to the institution of an action agains t a corporation in dissolution (now termination of corporate existence) at any time. United States v. Village Corp., 298 F.2d 816, 1962 U.S. App. LEXIS 6290 (4th Cir. 1962). Corporation not relieved of obligations by dissolution (no w termination of corporate existence) after transfer of assets.  See Pepper v. Dixie Splint Coal Co., 165 Va. 179, 181 S.E. 406, 1935 Va. LEXIS 286 (1935). Pending action not abated.  See Shepherd v. Kress Box Co., 154 Va. 421, 153 S.E. 649, 1930 Va. LEXIS 225 (1930). Vo luntary petition in bankruptcy contemplated by section.  The legislature contemplated a voluntary petition in bankruptcy as one of the means empowering officers, directors and shareholders of a dissolved corporation (no w corporation which has ceased to exist), to proceed as is provided in this section in its corporate name. In re Rust Control, Inc., 1 Bankr. 303, 1979 Bankr. LEXIS 757 (Bankr. W.D. Va. 1979). The filing of a voluntary petition in bankruptcy is one of the classic means of liquidating a defunct corporation, and the orderly processes of the bankruptcy sta tutes administered in the bankruptcy court protect the rights of all creditors in accordance with the validity and priorities of their respective claims and provide remedies for recovering property and voiding preferences which may have been granted some creditors. In re Rust Control, Inc., 1 Bankr. 303, 1979 Bankr. LEXIS 757 (Bankr. W.D. Va. 1979). Claim survives termination of corporate existence.  A corporation which had been involuntarily dissolved (now corporation whose existence has been terminated) by the Commission had the capacity to seek a determinat ion that its claim against a debtor was non-dischargeable in bankruptcy. Mining Env'ts, Inc. v. Staley, 43 Bankr. 374, 1984 Bankr. LEXIS 4808 (Bankr. W.D. Va. 1984). Liability for in jury occurring after dissolution.  A corporation cannot escape liability where, although the injury plaintiff complains of is related to a product purchased from defendant corporation, prior to dis solution, the claim did not arise until the injury occurred and the injury asserted occurred after dissolution. That result would be inconsistent with the clear intent of this section to abrogate the common-law rule which absolves a corporation of any li ability once that corporation is dissolved. Oliver v. AMC, 616 F. Supp. 714, 1985 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 16484 (E.D. Va. 1985). Absent an ulterior motive there is no basis for distinguishing between the eligibility of a debtor to file a Chapter 7 proceeding as opposed to a Chapter 11 proce eding when it has been terminated by the state. In re Wine Farms, Inc., 94 Bankr. 410, 1988 Bankr. LEXIS 2188 (Bankr. W.D. Va. 1988). A claim against a corporation must have existed or the liability of a corporation must have been incurred prior to the date of the corporations termination in order for the claim or liability to survive the termination. Thus, where executors cause of action did not arise until the accidental death of his decedent more than two years after corporation ceased to exist, the trial court correctly sustained co rporations demurrer. Harris v. T.I., Inc., 243 Va. 63, 413 S.E.2d 605, 8 Va. Law Rep. 1751, 1992 Va. LEXIS 149 (1992). Service of process upon president of a defunct corporation was proper, as this section e xpressly provides that a defunct corporation may be sued for liability incurred prior to the termination of its corporate existence, and since defendant defunct corporation could be sued as before, it could also be served with process as before. United S tates v. Moore, 698 F. Supp. 622, 1988 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 15700 (E.D. Va. 1988). Surety provided notice of proceeding s.  Since a subcontractor had notice of proceedings against it, as well as the trial courts two orders compelling the subcontractor to make available a corporate officer to be deposed, and that knowledge was imputed to its surety; nonetheless, the fact that the subcontractor was a defunct corporation did not alleviate its responsibility to name an officer to be present for the deposition. Am. Safety Cas. Ins. Co. v. C.G. Mitchell Constr., 268 Va. 340, 601 S.E.2d 633, 2004 Va. LEXIS 129 (2004).

405. Article 17. Foreign Corporations. -360§ 13.1-757. Authority to transact business required. -360§ 13.1-758. Consequences of transacting business without authority. -360§ 13.1-759. Application for certificate of authority. -360§ 13.1-760. Amended certificate of authority. -360§ 13.1-761. Effect of certificate of authority. -360§ 13.1-762. Corporate name of foreign corporation. -360§ 13.1-763. Registered office and registered agent of foreign corporation. -360§ 13.1-764. Change of registered office or registered agent of a foreign corporation. -360§ 13.1-765. Resignation of registered agent of foreign corporation. -360§ 13.1-766. Service of process on foreign corporation. -360§ 13.1-766.1. Merger of foreign corporation authorized to transact business in Commonwealth. -360§ 13.1-766.2. Conversion of foreign corporation authorized to transact business in Commonwealth. -360§ 13.1-767. Withdrawal of foreign corporation. -360§ 13.1-768. Automatic revocation of certificate of authority. -360§ 13.1-768.1. Repealed by Acts 2020, c. 1226, cl. 2, effective July 1, 2021. -360§ 13.1-769. Involuntary revocation of certificate of authority. -360§ 13.1-769.1. Reinstatement of a foreign corporations certificate of authority that has been withdrawn or revoked.

Text A. A foreign c orporation may not transact business in the Commonwealth until it obtains a certificate of authority from the Commission. B. The followi ng activities, among others, do not constitute transacting business within the meaning of subsection A: 1. Maint aining, defending, mediating, arbitrating, or settling any proceeding; 2. Holding meetings of the board of directors or shareholders or carrying on other activities concerning internal corporate affairs; 3. Maintaining accounts in financial institutions; 4. Maintaining offices or agencies for the transfer, exchange, and registration of the corporations own securities or maintaining trustees or depositories with respect to those securi ties; 5. Selling through independent contractors; 6. Soliciting or obtaining orders, by any means, if the orders require acceptance outside the Commonwealth before they become contracts; 7. Creating or acquiring indebtedness, deeds of trust, or security interests in property; 8. Securing or collecting debts or enforcing deeds of trust or security interests in property securing the debts, and holding, protecting, or maintaining property so acquired; 9. Owning, protecting, and maintaining property; 10. Conducting an isolated transaction that is completed within 30 consecutive days and that is not one in the course of similar transactions; 11. For a period of less than 90 consecutive days, producing, directing, filming, crewing, or acting in motion picture feature films, television series, or commercials, or promotional f ilms that are sent outside of the Commonwealth for processing, editing, marketing, and distribution; 12. Serving, without more, as a general partner of, or as a partner in a partnership which is a general partner of, a domestic or foreign limited partnership that does not otherwise tra nsact business in the Commonwealth; or 13. Transacting business in interstate commerce. C. The list of activities in subsection B is not exhaustive. D. This sectio n does not apply in determining the contacts or activities that may subject a foreign corporation to service of process, taxation, or regulation under the laws of the Commonwealth other than this chapter. E. The term transacting business as used in this section shall have no effect on personal jurisdiction under § 8.01-328.1. History History. Code 1950, §§ 13.1-102 to 13.1-102.2; 1956, c. 428; 1962, c . 239; 1980, c. 630; 1985, c. 522; 1990, c. 428; 2005, c. 765; 2019, c. 734. Annotations Cross references. As to registration and authority to transact business for financial institutions, see § 6.2-702. As to filing requirements for interstate branches of out-of-st ate banks, see Article 6 (§ 6.2-836 et seq.) of Chapter 8 of Title 6.2. As to additional filing requirements for out-of-state banks, see § 6.2-840. As to constitutional authority, see Va. Const., Art. IX, § 5. The 2005 amendments. The 2005 amendment by c. 765 substituted the Commonwealth for this Commonwealth in subsection A and subdivision B 12; deleted of this section  following subsection A in subsection B; substituted that does for which does in subdivision B 12; deleted of this section following subsection B in subsection C; and made minor stylistic changes. The 2019 amendments. The 2019 amendment by c. 734 rewrote this Code section. Law Review. For article, The New Virginia Stock Corporation Act: A Primer, see 20 U. Rich. L. Rev. 67 (1985). Michies Jurisprudence. For related discussion, see 4B M.J. Corporations, § 290; 15 M.J. Railroads, § 3. CASE NOTES Editors note. Many of the cases below were decided under prior law. Constitutionality.  Former § 163 of the Constitution precluded foreign corporations from exercising their functions in this State, except upon compliance with its laws, and expres sly authorized the General Assembly to discriminate against them. The General Assembly could exclude foreign corporations from exercising their functions within this State, subject only to the inhibition of the federal Constitution. Knights of KKK v. Com monwealth ex rel. SCC, 138 Va. 500, 122 S.E. 122, 1924 Va. LEXIS 41 (1924). Transactions constituting transacting business.  Transacting business in the State by a foreign corporation pursuant to this section and § 13.1-758 imports the transaction of its ordinary and customary busine ss herein. Conversely, business transactions of such corporation within the State which are not a part of its ordinary business but instead are merely incidental thereto are insufficient to constitute transacting business pursuant to this section and § 13.1-758. Continental Properties, Inc. v. Ullman Co., 436 F. Supp. 538, 1977 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 15906 (E.D. Va. 1977). A corporations sole connection to Virginia as a passive investor in notes secured by real estate located in the Commonwealth, did not constitute the transacti on of business in the state. Peterson v. Cooley, 142 F.3d 181, 1998 U.S. App. LEXIS 7687 (4th Cir. 1998). Business need not be commercial.  Doing business, as used in the statutes with reference to foreign corporations, is not confined to commercial or manufacturing functions only, but the exercise of its corporate functions by any foreign corporation within this State constitutes transacting business here within the meaning of the statutes. Knights of KKK v. Commonwealth ex rel. SCC, 138 Va. 500, 122 S.E. 122, 1924 Va. LEXIS 41 (1924). Thus, social business is included.  A patriotic, secret, social, benevolent, and foreign corporation, which established local organizations, initiated members and furnished them with paraphernalia, was exercising its functions and powers within this State, under the provisions of the statutes, and was therefore subject to the provisions thereof. Knights of KKK v. Commonwealth ex rel. SCC, 138 Va. 500, 122 S.E. 122, 1924 Va. LEXIS 41 (1924). A foreign corporation which solicits members, organizes lodges, distributes regalia, collects fees, and makes such contracts as are involved in or incidental to t hese acts, is protected under the provisions of law of this State, and the indirect connection with anything which could be fairly held to be interstate commerce is too remote to relieve it from the provisions of the statutes relating to foreign corporat ions. Knights of KKK v. Commonwealth ex rel. SCC, 138 Va. 500, 122 S.E. 122, 1924 Va. LEXIS 41 (1924). Illustrations of doing business.  The erection and installation within this State, by a foreign corporation, of a complete railway signal system, involving the employment of labor, skilled and uns killed, the stringing of wires, the construction of concrete foundations, and the erection and painting of signal mechanisms, all to be performed in this State, constitutes doing business in this State. General Ry. Signal Co. v. Commonwealth, 118 Va. 301 , 87 S.E. 598, 1916 Va. LEXIS 11 (1916), aff'd, 246 U.S. 500, 38 S. Ct. 360, 62 L. Ed. 854, 1918 U.S. LEXIS 1569 (1918). A foreign corporation which made a contract for the sale, installation and erection of certain gas machines and equipments in this State, involving extensive cons truction work, was doing business in this State, and therefore liable under § 13.1-758 for having failed to take out license therefor; the essence of the undertaking was the construction engaged in, the sale being a mere incident thereto. Commonwealth ex rel. SCC v. Western Gas Constr. Co., 11 Va. L. Reg. 737 (1926). The making of a contract out of this State by a foreign corporation, by which title to a tract of land within the State is acquired by such corporation, is not do ing business in the State, so as to render a director of the company liable for its debts under § 13.1-758, although the object of the purchase be to engage in mining in the State at a subsequent time. Goldsberry v. Carter, 100 Va. 438, 41 S.E. 858, 1 902 Va. LEXIS 42 (1902). A manufacturer which shipped goods on consignment to its exclusive distributor in Virginia, and, when the goods were sold by the distributor on conditional sales contracts, accepted assignment of the conditional sales contracts from the distributor, was not, under the facts, doing business in this State so as to subject it to the requirements of this article. Rock-Ola Mfg. Corp. v. Wertz, 249 F.2d 813, 1957 U.S. App. LEXIS 5431 (4th Cir. 1957). Entering into a purchase agreement for the sale of land to be used as a future manufacturing site does not constitute transacting business within the stat utory meaning of this section or § 13.1-758. Neither do the incidentals associated therewith, such as negotiating with and entering into construction contracts with an architectural firm, a general construction firm and a real estate development and i nvestment firm such as plaintiff. Continental Properties, Inc. v. Ullman Co., 436 F. Supp. 538, 1977 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 15906 (E.D. Va. 1977). Although plaintiff building and loan association was neither doing business nor was it authorized to do business in Virginia in accordance with Vi rginia law, the fact is that, lawfully, it had a substantial number of customers in Virginia and had made a number of loans secured by the pledge of real estate in this jurisdiction. In the context of an alleged misappropriation of a trade name, the real ity of a building and loan associations doing business ought to be considered by the court. Kyhos v. Perpetual Sav. & Loan Ass'n, 480 F.2d 204, 1973 U.S. App. LEXIS 9351 (4th Cir. 1973). Trademarks.  Although both the Georgia and Virginia Southern Christian Leadership Conferences (SCLC) operated in Virginia without proper authority, the Breakaway SCLCs reg istration of the service/trademarks did not defeat their continuous common-law use of the contested marks under § 59.1-92.3; therefore, the trial courts judgment that the Georgia SCLC and Virginia SCLC had a superior claim to the marks was not err oneous. SCLC v. Shannon, 270 Va. 104, 613 S.E.2d 596, 2005 Va. LEXIS 61 (2005). Interstate ...

akn:section.akn:heading: Consequences of transacting business without authority

akn:content.akn:p: Text A. A foreign c orporation transacting business in the Commonwealth without a certificate of authority may not maintain a proceeding in any court in the Commonwealth until it obtains a certificate of authority. B. The success or to a foreign corporation that transacted business in the Commonwealth without a certificate of authority and the assignee of a cause of action arising out of that business may not maintain a proceeding based on that cause of action in any court in the Commonwealth until the foreign corporation or its successor obtains a certificate of authority. C. A court may stay a proceeding commenced by a foreign corporation, its successor, or assignee until it determines whether the foreign corporation or its successor requires a certificate of authority. If it so determines, the court shall further stay the proceeding u ntil the foreign corporation or its successor obtains the certificate. D. If a foreig n corporation transacts business in the Commonwealth without a certificate of authority, each officer, director, and employee who does any of such business in the Commonwealth knowing that a certificate of authority is required shall be liable for a pena lty of not less than $500 and not more than $5,000. Any such penalty may be imposed by the Commission or by any court in the Commonwealth before which an action against the corporation may lie, after the corporation and the individual have been given not ice and an opportunity to be heard. E. Notwithstan ding subsections A and B, the failure of a foreign corporation to obtain a certificate of authority does not impair the validity of its corporate acts or prevent it from defending any proceeding in the Commonwealth. F. Suits, acti ons, and proceedings may be begun against a foreign corporation that transacts business in the Commonwealth without a certificate of authority by serving process on any director, officer, or agent of the corporation doing such business, or, if none can b e found, on the clerk of the Commission or on the corporation in any other manner permitted by law. If any foreign corporation transacts business in the Commonwealth without a certificate of authority, it shall by transacting such business be deemed to h ave thereby appointed the clerk of the Commission as an agent for service of process upon the foreign corporation. Service upon the clerk shall be made in accordance with § 12.1-19.1. History History. Code 1950, §§ 13-218, 13.1-119; 1956, c. 428; 1981, c. 320; 1985, c. 522; 1986, c. 571; 1990, c. 325; 1991, c. 672; 2005, c. 765; 2019, c. 734. Annotations Cross references. As to unlicensed public adjusters, see Article 3 (§ 38.2-812 et seq.) of Chapter 8 of Title 38.2. The 2005 amendments. The 2005 amendment by c. 765 substituted the Commonwealth for this Commonwealth throughout; deleted of this section following B in subsection E; in subsection F, inserted or on the corporation in any other manner permitted by law in the first sentence and in the third sentence, inserted upon the clerk and deleted on the clerk following made; and made minor stylistic changes. The 2019 amendments. The 2019 amendment by c. 734, in subsection F, substituted as an agent for its attorney, and inserted upon the foreign corporation followi ng of process. Law Review. For 1987 survey of Virginia business and corporate law, see 21 U. Rich. L. Rev. 645 (1987). Michies Jurisprudence. For related discussion, see 2A M.J. Attachment and Garnishment, § 11; 4B M.J. Corpora tions, §§ 290, 297; 11B M.J. Jurisdiction, § 15. CASE NOTES Editors note. Some of the cases below were decided under prior law. Liberal construction of former law.  See Knott Corp. v. Furman, 163 F.2d 199, 1947 U.S. App. LEXIS 2244 (4th Cir.), cert. denied, 332 U.S. 809, 68 S. Ct. 111, 92 L. Ed. 387, 1947 U.S. LEXIS 1716 (194 7). Engaging in business subjects foreign corporation to jurisdiction of state courts.  When a foreign corporation engages in the privilege of doing business in Virginia, it enjoys the benefits and protection of the laws of this Commonwealth. It ther eby subjects itself to the jurisdiction of the courts of this State for the purpose of litigating liabilities created during its stay here. Eure v. Morgan Jones & Co., 195 Va. 678, 79 S.E.2d 862, 1954 Va. LEXIS 147 (1954). Defendant was a Massachusetts corporation with the principal office in New York. It had not been domesticated in Virginia, had no resident agent here, and had not designated the Secretary of the Commonwealth (now the Clerk of the Commission) as its agent for service of process. Under such circumstances, it was necessary that defendant be engaged in business in the State in order to validate service upon it under this section which provides for service only if a corporation is so engaged. Carnegie v. Art Metal Constr. Co., 191 Va. 136, 60 S.E.2d 17, 1950 Va. LEXIS 206 (1950), limited, Eure v. Morgan Jones & Co., 195 Va. 678, 79 S.E.2d 862, 1954 Va. LEXIS 147 (195 4). A corporation which engages in business in the Commonwealth so as to enjoy the protections of its laws thereby subjects itself to the jurisdiction of the Commonwe alth. Pennington v. McDonnell Douglas Corp., 576 F. Supp. 868, 1983 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 11767 (E.D. Va. 1983). Which is not defeated by withdrawal from State.  A foreign corporation which does business in Virginia without domesticating or appointing a statutory agent nevertheless constitutes the Clerk of the Commission i ts agent for service of process. It may not, by withdrawing from the State, defeat an action growing out of business done in Virginia, and such action may be begun by substituted service. Eure v. Morgan Jones & Co., 195 Va. 678, 79 S.E.2d 862, 1954 Va. L EXIS 147 (1954). The only prerequisite of this section is that the corporation sought to be served must b e transacting business within the Commonwealth. Pennington v. McDonnell Douglas Corp., 576 F. Supp. 868, 1983 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 11767 (E.D. Va. 1983). There is no discernible distinction between the terms transacting business and doing business. Pennington v. McDonnell Douglas Corp., 576 F. Supp. 868, 1983 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 11767 (E.D. Va. 1983). The terms transacting business and doing business are used interchangeably by Virginia courts to describe the same action. The United States District Court, Eastern District of Virginia, will do the same. Continental Properties, Inc. v. Ullman Co., 436 F. Supp. 538, 1977 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 15906 (E.D. Va. 1977). Transactions constituting transacting business.  Transacting business in the State by a foreign corporation pursuant to § 13.1-757 and this section imports the transaction of its ordinary and customary busine ss herein. Conversely, business transactions of such corporation within the State which are not a part of its ordinary business but instead are merely incidental thereto are insufficient to constitute transacting business pursuant to § 13.1-75 7 and this section. Continental Properties, Inc. v. Ullman Co., 436 F. Supp. 538, 1977 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 15906 (E.D. Va. 1977). Entering into a purchase agreement for the sale of land to be used as a future manufacturing site does not constitute transacting business within the statutory meaning of § 13.1-757 or this section. Neither do the incidentals associated therewith, such as negotiating with and entering into construction contracts with an archi tectural firm, a general construction firm and a real estate development and investment firm such as plaintiff. Continental Properties, Inc. v. Ullman Co., 436 F. Supp. 538, 1977 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 15906 (E.D. Va. 1977). Merely ordering products or supplies in a forum state is not sufficient to find that a f oreign corporation is transacting business necessitating procurement of a certificate of authority. Questech, Inc. v. Liteco, AG, 735 F. Supp. 187, 1990 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 4419 (E.D. Va. 1990). Where the tortious injury does not arise out of in-state activities, a stronger showing of contacts between the defendant and the forum is required. The regularity test is applied in a situation where the cause of action did not arise from the in-state activity. The regularity test looks toward the continuity of business activity wi thin the forum. Pennington v. McDonnell Douglas Corp., 576 F. Supp. 868, 1983 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 11767 (E.D. Va. 1983). Complian ce with section before judgment is sufficient.  Maintain means a continuation of the proceeding already begun, and compliance with the requirements of this section before judgment is sufficient to entit le the corporation to continue its prosecution. Video Eng'r Co. v. Foto-Video Elecs., Inc., 207 Va. 1027, 154 S.E.2d 7, 1967 Va. LEXIS 173 (1967). Compliance with this section by a foreign corporation transacting business in this State after it has commenced an attachment proceeding is sufficient to enable i t to continue the action. Video Eng'r Co. v. Foto-Video Elecs., Inc., 207 Va. 1027, 154 S.E.2d 7, 1967 Va. LEXIS 173 (1967). Construction of prohibition against noncomplying corporations maintaining suits in state courts.  The prohibition against noncomplying corporations maintaining law suits in Virginia courts is not so much a defense available to a litigants adversaries, and therefore plausibly waivable, but it is rather an absolute bar to the offenders use of the courts to press its claim until compliance with the statutes is effected. Moore v. Northern Homes of Pa., Inc., 80 F.R.D. 278, 1978 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 15343 (W.D . Va. 1978). Effect of service on the Secretary of the Commonwealth.  Serving the Secretary of the Commonwealth pursuant to § 8.01-329 does not comply with the requirements of this section. Service upon the Secretary instead of t he Clerk of the Corporation Commission is ineffective. The defect is cured, however, by § 8.01-288 which states that [e]xcept for process commencing actions for divorce or annulment of marriage, process which has reached th...

Text A. To obtain a certificate of authority to transact business in the Commonwealth, a foreign corporation shall deliver an application to the Commission. The application shall be made on a form prescribed and furnished by the Commission. The application shall be signed in the name of the foreign corporation and set forth: 1. The n ame of the foreign corporation, and if the foreign corporation is prevented by § 13.1-762 from using its name in the Commonwealth, a designated name that satisfies the requirements of subsection B of § 13.1-762; 2. The foreign corporations jurisdiction of formation, and if the foreign corporation was previously authorized or registered to transact business in the Commonwealth as a foreign cor poration, limited liability company, business trust, limited partnership, or registered limited liability partnership, with respect to every such prior authorization or registration, (i) the name of the entity; (ii) the entity type; (iii) the state or ot her jurisdiction of incorporation, organization, or formation; and (iv) the entity identification number issued to it by the Commission; 3. The foreign corporations original date of incorporation, organization, or formation as an entity and its period of duration; 4. The street address of the foreign corporations principal office; 5.
